thread.title: Hone Harawira gets clear Te Tai Tokerau run for Mana not running against Maori Party in other seats
thread.title_full: Hone Harawira gets clear Te Tai Tokerau run for Mana not running against Maori Party in other seats

author: Jo Moir
title: Hone Harawira gets clear Te Tai Tokerau run for Mana not running against Maori Party in other seats
text:
Hone Harawira gets clear Te Tai Tokerau run for Mana not running against Maori Party in other seats JO MOIR Last updated 12:04, February 20 2017 
Mana leader Hone Harawira aligned with Kim Dotcom's Internet Party in 2014 and didn't make it back into Parliament. 
The Maori Party will not stand a candidate in Te Tai Tokerau against Mana leader Hone Harawira as part of a deal to claw back the Maori seats from Labour. 
While Maori Party co-leader Te Ururoa Flavell holds the Waiariki seat - the other six are held by Labour MPs - including Harawira's old seat, which he narrowly lost to Labour's Kelvin Davis in 2014. 
Under the agreement signed by the two parties in Whangarei on Monday, Harawira has agreed to not run any Mana candidates against the Maori Party in any of the other seats. WARWICK SMITH/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Maori Party and Mana Party welcomed on to Ratana together. From left; Mana Party leader Hone Harawira, Maori Party candidate for Te Tai Hauauru Howie Tamati, Maori Party co-leader Te Ururoa Flavell and Maori Party president Tuku Morgan. 
The Maori Party's candidate in Te Tai Tokerau won more than 2500 votes at the last election, so giving Harawira a clear run would put the pressure on Davis. 
READ MORE: 
But Davis isn't sweating over the agreement and says the "whole landscape has changed" in Te Tai Tokerau. DAVID WHITE/ FAIRFAX NZ 
Labour's Te Tai Tokerau MP Kelvin Davis narrowly won the seat from Mana leader Hone Harawira in 2014. 
"They're welcome to each other." 
"A vote for Mana now is a vote for the National Party and I think the people of Te Tai Tokerau will see that," he said. 
Three years on Davis says he's much more confident he'll win especially after his work in the corrections portfolio, including "a Minister losing his job and Serco losing its contract". DOMINICO ZAPATA/FAIRFAX NZ 
Labour MP Peeni Henare's Tamaki Makaurau seat is under threat with a unified Maori vote between Mana and the Maori Party. 
Davis was the driving force behind revelations around fight clubs and contraband in Serco-run prisons, which saw then-Corrections Minister Sam Lotu-Iiga come under fire and Corrections take over the running of Mt Eden prison. Ad Feedback 
Both Harawira and Maori Party president Tuku Morgan have agreed they need to stop splitting the Maori vote if they're going to have a chance of winning the seats back. 
"Māori disunity gifted the Māori seats to Labour in 2014 and it's time for us to bring all the seats home to kaupapa Māori parties so we can hold the balance of power in Parliament and ensure a strong voice in government, regardless of which major party rules," Morgan said. 
WHAT DOES A UNITED MAORI VOTE MEAN FOR LABOUR? 
The fight for the Maori seats has heated up this year with a resurgence from the Maori Party, which will only be enhanced with Mana out of the picture, and a promise to run high-profile candidates in the various electorates. 
So far the only big name revealed has been Howie Tamati, a former New Zealand league player and New Plymouth district councillor, who has been selected for the Te Tai Hauauru seat. 
The other big player aligned with the Maori Party was broadcaster Willie Jackson who was tipped to run in Tamaki Makaurau against Labour's Peeni Henare. 
However Labour leader Andrew Little approached Jackson to stand for the Opposition and the pair announced he would run on the party's list at Waitangi this year. 
Henare won the Auckland Maori seat with a majority of 1462 votes and a united Maori and Mana Party would pose a threat in the electorate, depending on who they find to run there now that Jackson is off the table. 
Henare revealed at Waitangi earlier this month that he had been asked by the party last year to stand aside in the electorate and run on the list but not because of Jackson joining - the former Alliance MP's move to the party came only recently. 
Little continues to deny that Henare was asked to step aside but it's clear the party has concerns about what a unified Maori vote would do for Henare's chances. 
Henare said on Monday following the announcement that the deal doesn't bother him at all. 
"I think our people deserve to see some policy and detail, not just the characters. 
"Moving forward I can't see any real threat until this election becomes an election debated on policies and decided on policies over personalities," he said. 
POLITICAL ATTACKS OFF THE TABLE 
The unity between Mana and the Maori Party extends to their approach to the election. The agreement stipulates "mutual respect" will be shown in the lead-up to the election, which means no political attacks on each other. 
Both parties will campaign for the party vote and the deal will end when voting in the general election on September 23 has closed. 
Morgan says since 2009 the Maori Party has delivered "more than $1 billion in funding for initiatives that benefit Maori". 
"Maori must ask themselves just what 80 years of allegiance to Labour has bought them. The alliance grew out of necessity but it did not stop the last Labour Government from legislating another raupatu or confiscation through the Foreshore and Seabed Act." - Stuff
